Comments_List: This course was an eye opening introduction to alternative histories of early America. I appreciated that it delved into numerous complicated issues like colonialism, native history, African American history, the American Revolution, etc.

This class did a great job of broadening the scope of Early American history. Countries and nation labels were more fluid in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries in the Americas and this class did a good job of bringing in narratives from Caribbean to Mainland US history.

The reading list was super interesting, and the professor was really insightful. However, I felt like the course could have had a more contiguous structure and more obvious central tenets to convey throughout the semester.

I think it was clear that this was Ittai's fist time teaching a full Yale class, so his arguements could be more fully formed and apparent. He needs to figure out a better way of structuring discussion so that he ensures that everything gets put on the table.
Yes! Definitely consider this course if you're interesting in learning about some very specific and interesting cases of resistance in early American history.
yes, take this course! super interesting counter narrative to American history. Not the stuff you learned in APUSH at all.
